CT SINUS/MANDIBLE/MAXILLOFACIAL

IMPRESSION: No fracture.

CT CHEST W/CONTRAST; CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST

IMPRESSION: Right anterolateral eighth and ninth rib fractures.
Hypoattenuation focus is seen subjacent to the fractures within
segement VIII of the liver and extending to the capsule, most
consistent with a small hematoma of biloma, consistent with a
grade II liver injury.

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST

NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT: No hemorrhage, hydrocephalus, or shift of
normally midline structures. The [**Doctor Last Name 352**]-white matter
differentiation is preserved. No major vascular territorial
infarct is apparent. The paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells
remain normally aerated. No fracture is identified. There is a
right periorbital hematoma. The globes and intraconal fat is
preserved.

IMPRESSION: No hemorrhage.


Brief Hospital Course:
She was admitted to the Trauma service. A ?small Grade I liver
hematoma was noted on CT imaging; she was observed on a regular
nursing unit; serial hematocrits were followed and remained
stable. She did have pain control issues requiring IV narcotics
initially; reporting that she has a high tolerance to pain
medication given prior use of narcotics from previous traumatic
injuries. She was later changed to oral narcotics with adequate
pain control.

Social work was closely involved in her care because surrounding
issues of coping and housing; she reportedly was recently
homeless after being asked to leave her mother's home. case
management became involved in trying to locate a facility that
would be able to manage her [**Hospital 75128**] medical issues.

Medications on Admission:
Ativan 2 mg tid/prn
"Anti-depressant"

s/p Motor vehicle crash

Discharge Instructions:
AVOID any contact sports or physical activity that may cause
injury to your abdominal region for the next 8 weeks.

You may wash your face with a gentle soap and pat dry, apply
Bacitracin ointment 3x/day until healed.

Return to the emergency room if you develop any fevers,
dizziness, lightheadedness, chills, increased pain not relieved
by your narcotics, abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting/diarrhea
and/or any other symptoms that are concerning to you.

Take your medications as preccribed.

Followup Instructions:
Follow up as needed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **], Trauma surgery, for any
concerns related to your recent car crash; call [**Telephone/Fax (1) 600**] if
an appointment is needed.
